title.narrative: Activity web page for IATI activity NL-1-PPR-28051

description.narrative: To contribute to preventing, promptly detecting and controlling the spread of the Ebola Virus Disease in Senegal and Guinea Bissau.

participating-org.narrative: Oxfam Novib is one of the 17 national affiliates of the Oxfam International Confederation. Oxfam started life in 1956 as the Netherlands Organisation for International Assistance (Novib), and joined forces with Oxfam in 1994. Working together in confederation, the Oxfam affiliates can speak with one clear and compelling voice on issues of global concern: climate change, health and education for all, agriculture, trade, and conflicts and emergencies. Oxfam Novib focus on these rights: The right to the resources for a sustainable livelihood The right to basic social services The right to life and security The right to social and political participation The right to an identity Oxfam Novib a défini dans sa stratégie 2012-2015 au Sénégal de travailler en partenariat avec les Organisations de la société civile sur des thématiques liées au moyens de subsistance durables, l#Education et à la participation politique.

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands

sector.narrative: The right to life and security

legacy-data.name: project-name
legacy-data.value: Preventing the Spread of the Ebola Virus

description.narrative: number of people that received humanitarian aid in disaster areas according to international standards
number of people that received humanitarian aid in disaster areas according to international standards

The #Preventing the Spread of the Ebola Virus in Senegal and Guinea-Bissau: Ensuring high-risk border regions are prepared to prevent, promptly detect and control the spread of disease# project is implemented by Oxfam in Senegal and Guinea Bissau along with the following project counterparts: the Associaçao Nacional para o Desenvolvimento Local Urbano (NADEL) in Guinea Bissau, Solidarité Action et Developpement (SADEV) and La Lumiére in Senegal. The project takes place in the Dakar, Tambacounda, Kolda and Kedougou regionsof Senegal and in the Tombali and Bijagos Island Regions of Guinea-Bissau and its main goal is to contribute to reducing the risk of Ebola Virus Disease (EVD) outbreak in Senegal and Guinea Bissau by undertaking social mobilization alongside the national governments# efforts. The project intends to target communities along the Senegal and Guinea Bissau borders with Guinea Conakry that are confronted with health, water and sanitation challenges as well as communities in densely populated cities and town. Medical practitioners at community levels and community health workers will also be targeted as key agents of change. Overall this project will reach 30,000 direct beneficiaries and 164,000 indirect beneficiaries with services including: hygiene kit distributions to vulnerable families; social mobilizations; information and education campaigns; trainings of community field workers, women#s groups and health facilities; training families in proper hygiene practices; stocking health facilities with preventive gear; strengthening community disease surveillance capacity; and rehabilitating wells to ensure access to clean water.
Oxfam is part of the consortium of INGOs and Government agencies implicated in the Ebola response. We work with the Consortium agencies to map our intervention areas and to avoid duplication of resources and also regularly participate in all Cluster Meetings (WASH and EFSVL) coordinated by OCHA for the EbolaCrisis. Oxfam has been running humanitarian and development programs in these project regions for over 7 years, concentrating primarily on food security, hygiene promotion and disease prevention. In Guinea-Bissau, we currently run a hygiene promotion program targeting cholera in the Tombali region, which we started in 2013, and a chlorine dispenser project in the Bijagos Islands with our partners NADEL and ADEMA. Oxfam will continue to work on well rehabilitation and hygiene promotion in these communities. In Senegal, we currently run: a sustainable flood risk management programme in the slums of Dakar; a WASH initiative in Kolda Region, which is an extension to our response to the 2012 food crisis in the region; a food security program in Kedougou, which includes hygiene and sanitation work; and a community-based microfinance program called Saving for Change as well as a rural resilience project with women groups in Tambacounda and Kolda.

participating-org.narrative: Nadel is a relatively young NGO that emerged from a former SNV project resulting in personnel with good capacities. Since 2001, theyear they started as an NGO, Nadel has been receiving various small finances from different donors, causing until now mostof the personnel working on a voluntary basis. With their local development schemes in Bissau, livelihood program in the Northern Province, Nadel continue to show good capacities as a networker and implementer. As such Nadel collaborates with institutionslike UNICEF, plan International, Oxfam Novib and Oxfam America in various areas including livelihoods, public health, education, etc

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands

sector.narrative: The right to life and security

The project intends to target communities along the Senegal and Guinea Bissau borders with Guinea Conakry that are confronted with health, water and sanitation challenges as well as communities in densely populated cities and town. participating-org.narrative: L#Association Kédougou Action Développement (A.K.A.D.) est née, pour contribuer et participer à cette autogestion, pour participer activement au développement de Kédougou par des actions de solidarités organisées, l#harmonisation des actions publiques etprivées dans le strict respect des droits des populations du Bélédougou du Bandemba ,du Niokolo, de Salémata ainsi que le Sirimana ,le Dantilla. C#est également pour participer dans la lutte pour le respect de l#environnement, pour la sauvegarde de la biodiversité, le respect des valeurs humaines etc.

sector.narrative: The right to basic social services

legacy-data.name: project-name
legacy-data.value: Preventing the Spread of the Ebola Virus

description.narrative: no. of women and men (youths) more able to make use of good preventive sexual reproductive health information and services (such as a constant offer at an affordable price of the female condom
no. of women and men (youths) more able to make use of good preventive sexual reproductive health information and services (such as a constant offer at an affordable price of the female condom

The Joint Humanitarian Response for Ebola (JRE) addresses the direct humanitarian needs as well as the indirect consequences related to the Ebola outbreak in West Africa. This 9-month joint programme is implemented in the 3 most affected countries, namely Liberia, Sierra Leone and Guinea, by 7 Dutch NGOs. Together they work towards four objectives. The first two objectives aim at stopping theEbola outbreak and treating the Ebola infected by identifying and tracing people with Ebola, supporting safe burials, providing health care for patients, promoting clinical hygiene in treatment and health care facilities, and ensuring medical care for health workers. Besides the direct health crises, the Ebola outbreak is having a wider impact on the general health system, security situation,economy and livelihoods in all affected countries. Therefore, the organisations also aim to ensure essential services and preserve stability by providing food and social safety net support, ensuring safe access to water and sanitation facilities, providing psycho-social support, increasing public awareness and social mobilization.

participating-org.narrative: Oxfam Great Britain is a member of Oxfam International, a confederation of independent national organisations working in more than 90 countries. Oxfam works on six goals that support the shared vision of a just world without poverty: help people claim their right to a better life; champion equal rights for women; saving lives, now and in the future; safeguard global food supplies; help people claim a fairer share of natural resources; and increase money for basic services. For 70 years, Oxfam has been running emergency responses, development projects and campaigning at the grass roots level to tackle poverty.

This 9-month joint programme is implemented in the 3 most affected countries, namely Liberia, Sierra Leone and Guinea, by 7 Dutch NGOs. Together they work towards four objectives. The first two objectives aim at stopping theEbola outbreak and treating the Ebola infected by identifying and tracing people with Ebola, supporting safe burials, providing health care for patients, promoting clinical hygiene in treatment and health care facilities, and ensuring medical care for health workers. Besides the direct health crises, the Ebola outbreak is having a wider impact on the general health system, security situation,economy and livelihoods in all affected countries. Therefore, the organisations also aim to ensure essential services and preserve stability by providing food and social safety net support, ensuring safe access to water and sanitation facilities, providing psycho-social support, increasing public awareness and social mobilization.

participating-org.narrative: CARE Nederland is part of CARE, an organization that fights for human dignity and less poverty around the world. CARE works in 86 countries and provides emergency relief to people affected by natural disasters and conflicts. CARE maintains long-term presence in disaster areas and immediately starts rebuilding, since that is what people need on the long run. CARE focuses on the provision of emergency relief, women empowerment, entrepreneurship and Disaster Risk Reduction. The organization strives after a world of hope, tolerance and social justice. By increasing the resilience of communities that are vulnerable to natural disasters and violent conflicts, Care contributes to sustainable solutions.

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands

This 9-month joint programme is implemented in the 3 most affected countries, namely Liberia, Sierra Leone and Guinea, by 7 Dutch NGOs. Together they work towards four objectives. The first two objectives aim at stopping theEbola outbreak and treating the Ebola infected by identifying and tracing people with Ebola, supporting safe burials, providing health care for patients, promoting clinical hygiene in treatment and health care facilities, and ensuring medical care for health workers. Besides the direct health crises, the Ebola outbreak is having a wider impact on the general health system, security situation,economy and livelihoods in all affected countries. Therefore, the organisations also aim to ensure essential services and preserve stability by providing food and social safety net support, ensuring safe access to water and sanitation facilities, providing psycho-social support, increasing public awareness and social mobilization.

participating-org.narrative: Cordaid is large development aid organisations in the Netherlands. Cordaid works closely with a network of partner organisations inAfrica, Asia, the Middle East and Latin America, and with Caritas Internationalis, of which Cordaid is the co-founder. Besides, Cordaid provides help to disadvantaged groups in the Netherlands itself. Cordaid aims to bring about transformation in societies aroundthe world so that they become more just, more inclusive and more sustainable. Focus areas of Cordaid’s work are health care, especially sexual and reproductive health, disaster response, sustainable use of natural resources, security and justice and women’s leadership.

This 9-month joint programme is implemented in the 3 most affected countries, namely Liberia, Sierra Leone and Guinea, by 7 Dutch NGOs. Together they work towards four objectives. The first two objectives aim at stopping theEbola outbreak and treating the Ebola infected by identifying and tracing people with Ebola, supporting safe burials, providing health care for patients, promoting clinical hygiene in treatment and health care facilities, and ensuring medical care for health workers. Besides the direct health crises, the Ebola outbreak is having a wider impact on the general health system, security situation,economy and livelihoods in all affected countries. Therefore, the organisations also aim to ensure essential services and preserve stability by providing food and social safety net support, ensuring safe access to water and sanitation facilities, providing psycho-social support, increasing public awareness and social mobilization.

participating-org.narrative: Plan Nederland, founded in 1975, is a member of the worldwide umbrella organization Plan International. Plan Nederland aims at sustainable poverty reduction and lasting improvements in the living condition of children. The organization pays special attention to equal rights and opportunities for girls and advocates for the rights of children and better compliance with the Convention on the Rights of the Child. Plan carries out child-centered community projects in 50 countries in Africa, Asia and Latin America. By listening to children and working together them, advocating for their rights, and enabling them and their families and communities to meet basic needs, Plan works towards concrete and sustainable improvements in the lives of children.

Besides the direct health crises, the Ebola outbreak is having a wider impact on the general health system, security situation,economy and livelihoods in all affected countries. Therefore, the organisations also aim to ensure essential services and preserve stability by providing food and social safety net support, ensuring safe access to water and sanitation facilities, providing psycho-social support, increasing public awareness and social mobilization.

participating-org.narrative: Save the Children, founded in 1919, works in approximately 120 countries. The organization has two core tasks: saving lives of children and saving dreams and futures of children. The organization helps children by providing support for health, education,protection and disaster relief. Save the Children supports children that are threatened, regardless of religion, sex, race, nationality or political opinion. All programmes of Save the Children are developed in cooperation with children, parents, governments, communities and other local partners in order to provide sustainable solutions.

title.narrative: Terre des Hommes/ Ebola Joint Response

description.narrative: The Joint Humanitarian Response for Ebola (JRE) addresses the direct humanitarian needs as well as the indirect consequences related to the Ebola outbreak in West Africa. This 9-month joint programme is implemented in the 3 most affected countries, namely Liberia, Sierra Leone and Guinea, by 7 Dutch NGOs. Together they work towards four objectives. The first two objectives aim at stopping theEbola outbreak and treating the Ebola infected by identifying and tracing people with Ebola, supporting safe burials, providing health care for patients, promoting clinical hygiene in treatment and health care facilities, and ensuring medical care for health workers. Besides the direct health crises, the Ebola outbreak is having a wider impact on the general health system, security situation,economy and livelihoods in all affected countries. Therefore, the organisations also aim to ensure essential services and preserve stability by providing food and social safety net support, ensuring safe access to water and sanitation facilities, providing psycho-social support, increasing public awareness and social mobilization.

participating-org.narrative: Terre des Hommes is an aid organization, founded in 1965, dedicated to stopping child exploitation in developing countries. By taking a goal and result-oriented approach, Terre des Hommes supports over 250 projects worldwide in the area of education, health care and independence. These projects are developed, established and implemented by local partners, so that activities can be geared closely to the practical requirements of the local population. Additionally, Terre des Hommes pursues a children’s rights campaign at national and international level consistent with the Convention on the Rights of the Child, both independently and in collaboration with local project partners.

The Joint Humanitarian Response for Ebola (JRE) addresses the direct humanitarian needs as well as the indirect consequences related to the Ebola outbreak in West Africa. This 9-month joint programme is implemented in the 3 most affected countries, namely Liberia, Sierra Leone and Guinea, by 7 Dutch NGOs. Together they work towards four objectives. The first two objectives aim at stopping theEbola outbreak and treating the Ebola infected by identifying and tracing people with Ebola, supporting safe burials, providing health care for patients, promoting clinical hygiene in treatment and health care facilities, and ensuring medical care for health workers. Besides the direct health crises, the Ebola outbreak is having a wider impact on the general health system, security situation,economy and livelihoods in all affected countries. Therefore, the organisations also aim to ensure essential services and preserve stability by providing food and social safety net support, ensuring safe access to water and sanitation facilities, providing psycho-social support, increasing public awareness and social mobilization.

participating-org.narrative: ZOA, founded in 1973 in the Netherlands, is a Christian international non-governmental organisation. The organisation supports people that are affected by armed conflict or natural disasters and helps them to rebuild their livelihoods. ZOA works in more than 15 countries and is committed to contribute to bringing real, tangible and sustainable change to the lives of affected people. ZOA focuses particularly on countries and areas within countries, categorised as 'fragile'. In ZOA's long term rehabilitation programmes, 'conflict-related fragility' is an essential characteristic on the context the organisation chooses to operate in. The sectorial focus of ZOA’s work is on livelihoods and food security, water, sanitation and hygiene and basic education. ZOA implements the Joint Response for Ebola in Liberia.

The Joint Humanitarian Response for Ebola (JRE) addresses the direct humanitarian needs as well as the indirect consequences related to the Ebola outbreak in West Africa. This 9-month joint programme is implemented in the 3 most affected countries, namely Liberia, Sierra Leone and Guinea, by 7 Dutch NGOs. Together they work towards four objectives. The first two objectives aim at stopping theEbola outbreak and treating the Ebola infected by identifying and tracing people with Ebola, supporting safe burials, providing health care for patients, promoting clinical hygiene in treatment and health care facilities, and ensuring medical care for health workers. Besides the direct health crises, the Ebola outbreak is having a wider impact on the general health system, security situation,economy and livelihoods in all affected countries. Therefore, the organisations also aim to ensure essential services and preserve stability by providing food and social safety net support, ensuring safe access to water and sanitation facilities, providing psycho-social support, increasing public awareness and social mobilization.

participating-org.narrative: Oxfam Novib was founded in 1956 as the Netherlands Organisation for International Assistance (Novib), and joined forces with Oxfam in 1994. Oxfam Novib is member of the Oxfam International confederation. Working together in the confederation, the Oxfam affiliates can speak with one clear and compelling voice on issues of global concern: climate change, health and education for all, agriculture, trade, and conflicts and emergencies. Oxfam Novib's main office is based in The Netherlands, it supports the work of a network of local offices, the implementation of global projects, fundraising, campaigning and advocacy. Oxfam Novib’s the Hague office contributes towards this project’s implementation.

Oxfam America is a global organization working to right the wrongs of poverty, hunger, and injustice. As one of 17 members of the international Oxfam confederation, we work with people in more than 90 countries to create lasting solutions. Oxfam saves lives, develops long-term solutions to poverty, and campaigns for social change.
its vision: A just world without poverty.
its mission: To create lasting solutions to poverty, hunger, and social injustice.

Oxfam's communication campaign, Supporting and Monitoring the Effective Governance of the Ebola Epidemic Response in the ECOWAS region. In view of the current Ebola epidemic, the Regional Good Governance Campaign addresses the current regional circumstances hindering pre-existing objectives in West Africa.
West Africa Democracy Radio WADR will implement a communication campaign aimed at building a media infrastructure (beginning with radio and ICT/ web and mobile and video for dissemination on social media) and capacityto supporting and monitoring the good governance response to the Ebola epidemic. This will increase CSO and social participation inresponse efforts. The Campaign is aimed at the following targets: 1. ECOWAS Citizens at large, with focus on women and youth; and regional and national CSO and media in the 15 Member States and the Diaspora. 2. ECOWAS Governments with particular stress on national Implementation cells in charge of the coordination of the national implementation of ECOWAS law and policy, customs, border areas and airports. 3. The private sector: the Campaign will influence integrated economic development in West Africa by engaging all branches in campaigning.
This Active Citizenship Campaign supports and monitor via Radio FM/AM, Web Radio <(>&<)> Social Networks with these specific objectives: 1. Give information and communication to communities and mobilize actors in a coordinated media response at local, national and regional levels. 2. Monitor the Ebola response strategies in the region focusing on good governance, access to information, freedom of expression and gender issues by strengthening the capacities of WADR journalists and the journalists of partner radio stations. 3. To produce quality, ethical information and multimedia programs on the Ebola Virus Disease .

participating-org.narrative: The West Africa Democracy Radio (WADR) is a trans-territorial, sub-regional radio station based in Dakar, Senegal. WADR was established in 2005 as a project of the Open Society Initiative for West Africa (OSIWA) to, among other objectives, protect and defend the ideals of democratic and open societies by disseminating development information through a network of community radios in the West African sub-region. The mission of WADR is the promotion and defence of the ideals of democracy, openness, mutual understanding and respect between individuals and between communities. This regional radio entity also seeks to promote peace and human security, transparency and the duty to report on governance, regional economic integration, as well as social and cultural development amongst and between the peoples of the West African region. Through its programs, the WADR seeks to provide a forum for diverse opinions to create understanding among people and between people and their governments.

The funds contributed to the implementation of the EVD response strategy in Liberia. Oxfam’s long-standing presence in Liberia positioned Oxfam well to respond to the Ebola Virus Disease (EVD) emergency response. By considering the health impacts of WASH programming, Oxfam offered its expertise to improve WASH infrastructure in health facilities and schools while encouraging communities to improve hygiene practices and health seeking behaviour. As a result, communities were supported in taking up disease prevention measures and resuming day-to-day activities as the EVD caseload reduced. Shortly after the end of the EVD emergency, Oxfam conducted a short-term cash transfer programme to inject much needed financial support into food insecure counties. Through a two-pronged approach of cash for work for households capable of restarting rice cultivation and unconditional cash grants for highly vulnerable households, Oxfam continued to address immediate needs resulting from the multi-sectoral impacts of the outbreak.

participating-org.narrative: Oxfam Great Britain is a member of Oxfam International, a confederation of independent national organisations working in more than 90 countries. Oxfam works on six goals that support the shared vision of a just world without poverty: help people claim their right to a better life; champion equal rights for women; saving lives, now and in the future; safeguard global food supplies; help people claim a fairer share of natural resources; and increase money for basic services. For 70 years, Oxfam has been running emergency responses, development projects and campaigning at the grass roots level to tackle poverty.

This project is a preventive intervention against Ebola and other epidemics including Cholera in Mbogoswa Island, Bangui, Ombella M'Poko in Central African Republic. The project will run over 3 month (from 01/06/2018 to 31/08/2018) with a budget of 151.690 #. Thedirect beneficiaries of the project will be 500 households, or 3,000 people composed mainly of the Mbogoswa island population, the Oubangui River fishermen, the sand operators of the Port Beach and the Zongo-RDC travelers from Bangui's Port Beach. Oxfam will alsoreach 3 community protection committees consisting of 7 people each. The overall goal of the project is to improve the response capacity of Mbogswa Island communities to Ebola epidemics. For this intervention, Oxfam intends to put in place the following strategy:i) provision of a package of key Ebola prevention activities to support 500 households ii) capacity building of local structures for Ebola prevention iii) strengthening of the information system and monitoring with the WaSH Cluster and the authorities.

participating-org.narrative:
Oxfam is an international confederation of 17 organizations working together in more than 90 countries. Oxfam International was formed in 1995 by a group of independent non-governmental organizations. Their aim was to work together for greater impact on the international stage to reduce poverty and injustice. The name “Oxfam comes from the Oxford Committee for Famine Relief, founded in Britain in 1942. The group campaigned for food supplies to be sent through an allied naval blockade to starving women and children in enemy-occupied Greece during the Second World War. As well as becoming a world leader in the delivery of emergency relief, Oxfam International implements long-term development programs in vulnerable communities. We are also part of a globalmovement, campaigning with others, for instance, to end unfair trade rules, demand better health and education services for all, and to combat climate change. Today, there are 17 member organizations of the Oxfam International confederation. They are based in: Australia, Belgium, Canada, France, Germany, Great Britain, Hong Kong, Ireland, India, Italy, Japan, Mexico, The Netherlands, New Zealand, Quebec, Spain and the United States. The Oxfam International Secretariat is based in Oxford, UK. The Secretariat runs advocacy offices in Brussels, Geneva, New York, Washington DC and Brasilia.
Intermon Oxfam is an actor in the implementation of this project.

This project will be focussed on addressing key gaps highlighted by country teams in the priority countries which Oxfam could support. The HECA regional platform will work with the priority country teams to ensure a coherent approach in both Ebola spreadprevention and equipping of teams for response in the event there is an outbreak in their respective countries. Key preparedness activities will include building staff capacity on community engagement and Ebola response actions, developing community engagement plans with communities in high risk locations, conducting of simulation exercises, conducting assessments for and supporting installation of WASH facilities in identified ETCs, preparing of contingency stock and coordination with local and nationalstructures on Ebola preparedness. The following are the proposed activities per country: Uganda i) Conducting of community engagement activities including vulnerability assessments, community mobilisation and awareness creation (using dialogue meetings, radio shows, working with village health workers) on Ebola prevention and preparedness for approximately 28,711 people in five zones in Kyaka settlement. ii) Assessment and establishing of WASH emergency response kits for 10 treatment facilities including handwashing facilities and disinfection kits iii) Development and production of IEC material for Ebola awareness iv) Training and capacity building of approximately 20 Oxfam and partner staff v) Procurement of personal protection equipment for 10 Oxfam staff operating at the reception centre and contingency stock for Ebola response vi) Conducting of a technical review of the Ebola preparedness and response plan to inform updates in the national EVD preparedness plan. This includes supporting 2 EVD district coordination meetings

participating-org.narrative: Oxfam Novib is one of the 17 national affiliates of the Oxfam International Confederation. It started life in 1956 as the Netherlands Organisation for International Assistance (Novib), and joined forces with Oxfam in 1994. Working together in confederation, the Oxfam affiliates can speak with one clear and compelling voice on issues of global concern: climate change, health and education forall, agriculture, trade, and conflicts and emergencies. Oxfam established this country office to support local organizations and projects. Through this local office Oxfam Novib directly contributes towards this project’s implementation.

Foundation for Urban and Rural Advancement (FURA) will raise awareness on Ebola through the local radios and through her existing structures like community groups in both districts mentioned, community volunteers and Interventions like conducting radio talk shows, carrying out community level meetings on Ebola and composing a song on Ebola using the local artist that will be played on local radios every after news. FURA will work closely with the District health team/DHOs office to conduct meetings, trainings and radio talk shows. FURA will work in 14 subconties of Kasese district that are deemed to be at risk because of its location and business related aspects by its residents. These are Bwera, Mbondwelhubiriha town council, Karambi, Nyakiyumbu, katwe kabatoro town council, Ihandiro, Kitholhu, Kisinga, Kyalhumba, Kahokya, Muhokya,Mahango, Central Division and Nyamwamba(Kasese Municipality) and will closely work with the Village health teams, schools, FURA community Volunteers, community leaders and proposes to support DTF on coordinationareas. Response objective: TO Enhance the knowledge of targeted 50,000 local populations from 7 sub counties of Kasese district on EVD by the end of September 2019 Outcomes # Enhancing the knowledge of local communities on Ebola virus disease (EVD) # Communities are aware and leaders know their roles and responsibilities in the EVD prevention at all levels. # Ensuring Availability of basic Ebola Virus disease prevention materials at 200 schools. Activities # Conducting radio talk shows and spots on Ebola virus prevention on 3 local radio stations. # Improving capacity of FURA staff and volunteers to respond. # Supporting of 200 schools with hand washing facilities with its accessories including Jik. # Conduct community engagement meetings with various stakeholders including religious leaders, local councils. Conduct meetings with various community groups (Women, Youth. # Documentation of alerts, rumors and reporting of various activities. # Conduct School EVD awareness and personal protection campaigns # Distribution of IEC materials developed by MOH. # Operational support to the FURA and DTF

participating-org.narrative: Foundation for urban and rural advancement is a registered, indigenous non-profit humanitarian service and development organizationfounded in 1993 to provide service to the urban and rural poor communities of Kasese and beyond. In pursuit of her vision-a #community of health, informed and harmonious persons meeting their basic needs with ease,# FURA Uganda has over the last 19years become one of the most leading organizations in livelihoods in rwenzori region. to date, in bid to address the problem of urban and rural poverty, food security, poor service delivery by government and ensure improved livelihoods food security, citizen engagement and social accountability and building communities resilience to disasters, FURA operates at community, regional and national levels. FURA IS registered as an NGO number 1233 and as accompany limited by guarantee without share capital in the ministry of justice and constitutional affairs registration number 69927. The primary constituency of FURA#S work is the rural and urban poor, especially the most disadvantaged communities affected by conflicts and other humanitarian crisis.FURA intervenes in awide range of disaster Prepared and management, livelihoods, governance, advocacy and community empowerment issues such as savings and loans associations, citizen engagement and social accountability, school gardening and parent led gardens, NAADS monitoring, disaster risk reduction and advocacy for the elderly. FURA#S activities and programmatic competencies are organized around four thematic areas of # Sustainable livelihoods # Disaster preparedness and management # Advocacy and human rights # Research, consultancy and information management. FURA Over the years has undertaken and delivered capacity building, advocacy and alliance building, direct action on poverty, research, learning and publications in response to the extreme poverty and suffering among communities. The vast experience generated through these interventions accounts for FURA#S competences in livelihoods work which include Improving access to reliable savings and credit management system, equip clients with business skills, adopting a user friendly M<(>&<)>E system for SPM and VA model, Enhancing resilience of poor women and men agricultural producersin vulnerable communities to disaster risks and climate variations, improving access of producer groups to NAADS services in Kasese district, enabling increase in food security through increased productivity andincomes at household level, improving the quality of education at primary school level through effective participation of parents in school activities, acting as learning centre for good agronomic practices that increases adoption of good agricultural practicesand innovations in communities and Process documentation, Contributing to an enabling environment for government accountability in Kasese district that fosters active participation of citizens and enhances access of poor communities to government services. FURA Uganda has its headquarters located in Kilembe quarters, Kasese municipal council, through which sub county and district level activities are conducted. FURA works in all the 28 sub counties of Kasese district, 4town councils and in the municipality. In addition tothis, FURA also extends services to the districts of Bundibugyo and Ntoroko. Also in emergencies, FURA goes beyond Rwenzori region and covers all parts of the country in response to emergencies. Currently FURA responds to EBOLA outbreak.

African Women and Youth Action for Development (AWYAD) is a humanitarian NGO partner working in South Western Uganda/Kyaka II implementing refugee response interventions in partnership with Oxfam. AWYAD and Oxfam have co-created a humanitarian response intervention on Protection of refugees and host communities. This is in response to the DRC refugee influx in the region following the outbreak of fighting in their country. The conflicts in DRC have persisted and coupled with EBOLA outbreak and elections, the number of new refugees has continued to grow (currently at approximately about 150,000 in Kyaka II and Kyangwali) and there is no return envisaged in the medium term. AWYAD will lead implementation of project activities regarding gender, Protectionand humanitarian advocacy among refugees and host communities in Kyaka II (Kyegegwa) settlement. The proposed interventions will target a total of 33,600 beneficiaries (48% male and 52% female) who will benefit from integrated services. The ratio betweenhost communities and refugee communities will be respectively 30% and 70% (as per government of Uganda#s policy).
The proposed interventions compliment OXFAM humanitarian work in the target communities. (through improving safety and self reliance for DRC displaced populations and host communities inKyaka and Kyangwali settlements in western Uganda. The project Outcomes include the following: # 66.600 women and men in target communities are better able to identify, prevent, mitigate and respond to protection threats # Strengthened humanitarian advocacy andcoordination mechanisms.

participating-org.narrative: African Women and Youth Action for Development (AWYAD) is a Non-Government Organization (NGO) founded by Christians with a deep concern for vulnerable youth and women in Uganda, South Sudan, Kenya and Tanzania in the East African Region, living in abjectpoverty and whose voices cannot be heard. AWYAD was established 2010, by Christians with a passion to support vulnerable youth and women groups in various parts of the region, where 78% of youth are enslaved in the war of want, unintended self-torture, unproductiveness, crime, hunger and stress due to poverty as a result of joblessness and hopelessness. Over 70% of women in many rural communities live through untold suffering caused by horror of poverty associated with cultural and economic injustices such as discrimination and unpaid labour which is both on and off farm. During emergencies like sever famine and hunger and displacement, women and children suffer most from the consequences of the disaster. In order to overcome these challenges, AWYAD isdriven with a passion to work and advocate for change that eradicates the causes of poverty, discrimination and injustice striving to achieve equality, voice and empowerment. The organization targets vulnerable youth between the age of 15 <(>&<)> 30 years andvulnerable women including young single mothers, widows, women with HIV and disability with competitive skills and knowledge on agro business, promoting talent, innovation andentrepreneurship as well as nurturing and mentoring youth and women leaders withskills to influence, participate in decision makingfor the development of their families, their communities and nation.

The project will reach out to a total 15,000 individuals in Kasese district, the worst affected area with the current floods., Focus will be on provision of life saving essential WASH interventions including construction of emergency latrines and bathing shelters, distribution of essential WASH NFIs (containers for water collection and distribution, household water treatment chemicals, soap etc), Rehabilitation of damaged water systems (handpumps springs etc) Hygiene Promotion using both contact and non-contact based approaches. Oxfam will implement the response in partnership with FURA, a local Oxfam partner within the region with operations and establishments in Kasese. FURA has good knowledge of the geography, social and cultural set up of the area and previously worked with Oxfam on the Ebola Preparedness and response interventions in Kasese. FURA will implement software activities such as distribution ofWASH NFIs, community engagement and risk communication community sensitization through all available mechanisms. Oxfam will provideoverall technical back stopping and implementation of major technical infrastructural activities in collaboration with district line departments and FURA
Rehabilitation of broken-down bore holes, damaged pipe lines and protected springs within the affected areas. At least 7 bore holes, and 2 protected springs will be rehabilitated in the Kasese district to restore back safe water supply to these affected villages. The rehabilitation will include well redevelopment, replacement of worn out parts, reconstruction of embankment walls for the protected springs and disinfection for rehabilitated systems
Distribution of Household Water treatment tablets: At least 15 boxes of water treatment tablets will be distributed to the affected population in Kasese districts. This will support water quality improvement in areas relying on contaminated water sources thus avoid possible outbreak of water borne diseases including cholera. Oxfam and partner will work with Village Health Teams (VHTs) to facilitate demonstrations on appropriate use and water quality monitoring. This will be a short-term measure and will be stopped immediately rehabilitation of damaged water sources is complete.
Procurement and distribution of household hygiene kits such as water collection and storage containers as well as soap will bedistributed to affected households targeting at least 750 households. The WASH NFIs will include 750 Jerry cans of 20 litres, 750 drinking water buckets, and 100 cartoons of soap. This will support strengthening safe water chain management at household level as well as well us practice of handwashing with soap particularly in this period of COVID 19.
Water quality monitoring for both bacteriological and FRC will be undertaken at all water sources with the affected areas. The project will support the district water departments to strengthen water quality monitoring to ensure that affected communities are accessing safe water.
Construction of communallatrines and bath shelters at evacuation centres, 20 gender segregated communal latrines and bathe shelters will be constructed at evacuation centres and hand washing facilities installed in areas where they do not exist, this will be accompanied by hygiene promotion activities. This will enhance good hygiene and sanitation practices to avoid disease outbreak at evacuation centres. Latrine cleaning tools and detergents will be procured and distributed to all evacuation centres where communal latrines have been set up, communities will be mobilized to ensure continued cleaning of latrines and refilling of hand washing facilities on rotation basis for easy operation and maintenance of the facilities.
Procurement and distribution of waste mobile bins at evacuation centres. At least 10 waste mobile bins for solid waste collection and transportation to rubbish pits will be procured and distributed to evacuation centres. This will help address the challenges of vermin as well as enhance vector control and avoid diseases at the centres.
Community dialogues with the affected people will be conducted, this will enhance community participation and ensure two-way communication between the partners and affected communities across the 3 affected districts. At least 2 meetings will be conducted amongst the affected communities in Kasese District.
Reproduction and dissemination of IEC materials on hygiene and sanitation promotion, as well COVID 19 prevention measures. Billboards, PVC burners and flyers depicting key messages will be produced, installed and distributed in strategic locations at community level.
Post distribution monitoring, the project will also conduct post distribution monitoringexercises for WASH NFIs distributed. Joint monitoring exercise will be done to enhance quality implementation of the project

participating-org.narrative: Foundation for urban and rural advancement is a registered, indigenous non-profit humanitarian service and development organizationfounded in 1993 to provide service to the urban and rural poor communities of Kasese and beyond. In pursuit of her vision-a #community of health, informed and harmonious persons meeting their basic needs with ease,# FURA Uganda has over the last 19years become one of the most leading organizations in livelihoods in rwenzori region. to date, in bid to address the problem of urban and rural poverty, food security, poor service delivery by government and ensure improved livelihoods food security, citizen engagement and social accountability and building communities resilience to disasters, FURA operates at community, regional and national levels. FURA IS registered as an NGO number 1233 and as accompany limited by guarantee without share capital in the ministry of justice and constitutional affairs registration number 69927. The primary constituency of FURA#S work is the rural and urban poor, especially the most disadvantaged communities affected by conflicts and other humanitarian crisis.FURA intervenes in awide range of disaster Prepared and management, livelihoods, governance, advocacy and community empowerment issues such as savings and loans associations, citizen engagement and social accountability, school gardening and parent led gardens, NAADS monitoring, disaster risk reduction and advocacy for the elderly. FURA#S activities and programmatic competencies are organized around four thematic areas of # Sustainable livelihoods # Disaster preparedness and management # Advocacy and human rights # Research, consultancy and information management. FURA Over the years has undertaken and delivered capacity building, advocacy and alliance building, direct action on poverty, research, learning and publications in response to the extreme poverty and suffering among communities. The vast experience generated through these interventions accounts for FURA#S competences in livelihoods work which include Improving access to reliable savings and credit management system, equip clients with business skills, adopting a user friendly M<(>&<)>E system for SPM and VA model, Enhancing resilience of poor women and men agricultural producersin vulnerable communities to disaster risks and climate variations, improving access of producer groups to NAADS services in Kasese district, enabling increase in food security through increased productivity andincomes at household level, improving the quality of education at primary school level through effective participation of parents in school activities, acting as learning centre for good agronomic practices that increases adoption of good agricultural practicesand innovations in communities and Process documentation, Contributing to an enabling environment for government accountability in Kasese district that fosters active participation of citizens and enhances access of poor communities to government services. FURA Uganda has its headquarters located in Kilembe quarters, Kasese municipal council, through which sub county and district level activities are conducted. FURA works in all the 28 sub counties of Kasese district, 4town councils and in the municipality. In addition tothis, FURA also extends services to the districts of Bundibugyo and Ntoroko. Also in emergencies, FURA goes beyond Rwenzori region and covers all parts of the country in response to emergencies. Currently FURA responds to EBOLA outbreak.
